MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Matter. - Williamstown (Galway) National School.

Speaker.P: I apologise to the House for being late. I was sitting in my office. I did not expect the debate to end so quickly, as it was scheduled to last until about 8 o'clock. I also beg your indulgence for the fact that I am suffering from a cold, if not a flu, so my contribution may be interspersed with bouts of coughing and other throat clearing exercises but I imagine, Sir, that you will bear with me and that the Official Reporters will bear with me also.

The present school in Williamstown was built and opened in 1943. At the time of opening it consisted of a boys' school and there was also a school for girls. In the early sixties the numbers increased in both schools and the catering or lunch rooms in both the schools had to be turned into classrooms. By 1963 there were four teachers in Williamstown, two in each school. In 1967 another school in the parish of Leitra was amalgamated with Williamstown. At that time some repairs were carried out to the building and a new water supply, electric lighting and a new central heating system were installed. In 1974 the two schools in Williamstown and the manager, under very persistent pressure from the Department of Education, agreed to the amalgamation of all the schools in the parish of Williamstown, namely, Farm School, Poilredmond School and Williamstown boys' and girls' schools. The amalgamation was accepted on the condition that the Department would shortly afterwards sanction the provision of a general purpose room, improved toilet facilities and other small ancillary services on the site. There was an absolute guarantee given at that time by the Department's inspector who supervised the amalgamation that these minimal requirements would be sanctioned. The management, teachers, parents and pupils agreed to the amalgamation, based on the urgings and guarantees of the Department. They honoured their end of the bargain fully. Once the amalgamation was in place the Department quickly welshed on their promise and today 13 years later the promise remains broken.

MainHeading.P: Now there are 215 pupils on the school roll and they are packed into a building that was meant to accommodate 150 children at most. They are crowded into four under-sized and sub-standard classrooms of the early forties vintage and two other classrooms that were originally tea rooms for the pupils. They have toilet and cloakroom facilities for 150 children and a small staff room which holds three people, even though there are six teachers on the staff. Three years ago the manager of the school started to campaign in earnest to get something done about the appalling overcrowding and the general deteriorating condition of the school. The then Minister for Education, Deputy Hussey, recognised the plight of everyone involved and to her great credit she sanctioned the following improvements: first, the existing six sub-standard classrooms in the old main building were to be re-ordered to create four up-to-date and up to standard rooms; second, a new extension would be constructed consisting of two new classrooms, a general purposes room, new, adequate toilet and cloakroom facilities, a staff room and a small library-cum-medical room.

The various stages of planning were submitted and sanctioned very speedily by the Minister, Deputy Hussey and later by Deputy Cooney. In February of this year the project was released to tender. The contractors' tenders were submitted to the Department's building section on 19 March and the contractor was chosen but never appointed because, by the month of May, all proposals for school building and improvement were put into deep freeze by the new Minister. We want these proposals taken out of the deep freeze because this is a most deserving emergency case. It is one of the most grossly over-crowded schools in the country with pupils and teachers living a kind of sardines in a tin existence. The Minister will agree with me that this is the least conducive atmosphere for good teaching and good learning.

The condition of the existing structure is not the worst in the country — I spoke about Frenchpark here six weeks ago — but the structure in Williamstown is deteriorating. The Minister has been made aware of the broken promise of 1974. Do not add another despicable chapter to that, with another broken promise. I ask the Minister not to trot out the usual blah blah about shortage of money and the number of school projects released to tender by the Coalition. I repeat this case is an emergency and we do not want half or quarter measures in response, similar to the response we got to Frenchpark where the grant allocation was cut by almost two-thirds. There is no credibility in telling us there is no money to deal with an emergency like Williamstown.

In the past week we have seen a seven room school sanctioned in Calry, County Sligo. I wish in no way to decry or take away from the sanction for Calry school. I have no doubt it is a fully deserving case and I wish them continued luck. But, I remain with a sneaking suspicion that their luck in being sanctioned having gone to tender last September has something to do with the fact that Calry is bang in the centre of the constituency of the Minister for Finance. It is only about four miles from his home. My appeal to the Minister on behalf of Williamstown, as it was on behalf of Frenchpark six weeks ago, is not based on politics or political proximity to someone with power over the public purse. It is based instead on the need of disadvantaged children in a disadvantaged school. I expect the Minister's response to be based on the over-riding criteria of need, aside from political consequences or non-consequences.

I have one final point. Under the regulations that predate Circular 20/87 this school is entitled to another teacher commencing on 1 January. The numbers are there to justify the appointment of an additional teacher, and have been there for the stipulated length of time. In view of the fact that we now understand that this nefarious little circular is being withdrawn, would the Minister confirm for me tonight in order that I can communicate with the manager and his board that they can go ahead and appoint the additional teacher with effect from the term commencing after Christmas? Our appeal stands and we hope we will have a positive response from the Minister.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Education (Mr. F. Fahey) Frank Fahey
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Education (Mr. F. Fahey)
Speaker.P: My Department's records show that the authorities of Williamstown national school, County Galway, applied in 1982 for a grant towards the cost of upgrading and extending the accommodation of their building. The school currently has six teachers, including the principal, and classes are accommodated in six classrooms of traditional construction. My understanding is that the school is well maintained but that the small size of the classrooms gives rise to a problem of overcrowding. The proposal which has been submitted and which my Department are prepared in principle to grant-aid is the conversion of the present six classrooms into four by altering the internal walls, and the provision of two permanent classrooms, together with a general purposes area and the usual ancillary areas for a school of this size.

The invitation of tenders for the project by the school authorities, as the Senator rightly pointed out, was authorised in January or February last by my predecessor in office. Tenders were, in fact, invited and the recommendation of the school's professional consultants thereon have been submitted for my Department's consultation. Because, however, of the pressure on the limited capital available to my Department for the national school buildings programme, I am not in a position at this stage to authorise further movement on the project.

MainHeading.P: I have not had an opportunity at this stage to consult with the school authorities as to whether there are any interim measures which can be taken to alleviate pressure on the existing accommodation at the school. I hesitate in this context to go into detail as to the options which may be available in the circumstances. I understand that the chairman of the school's board of management has been making inquiries as to the prospects of movement on this project but, so far, because of the present difficult financial climate, my Department have been unable to hazard a timescale for the completion of the tender action and contract formalities.

However, in the light of the case put by the Senator, I propose to make arrangements for a senior official from the primary buildings branch of my Department to make contact with the manager of the school with a view to discussing the school's difficulties and establishing whether, with the limited finances that are available some relief could be afforded to the school.

With regard to the last point made by the Senator, Circular 20/87 has not been withdrawn but guidelines have been authorised by the Minister under which we will examine the situation with regard to the appointment the Senator has mentioned, with a view to sorting out the problem that has arisen.
